div1.p: Hench gives an account of the Lazear family since the death of Jesse W. Lazear. Hench discusses a rift in the Lazear family.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench, January 22, 1955
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
January 22, 1955
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
Captain and Mrs. James O. Gawne of Washington, D.C. and Mr. and Mrs. John
Lazear of Naples, Florida and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, intend to fly to
Havana sometime between February 15 and 24 for the sole purpose of seeing
Camp Lazear.

Mrs. Gawne was Jane Lazear and she and her brother (who will be with her)
are the first cousins of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear of yellow fever fame after
whom Camp Lazear was named. They are of course anxious not only to see
Camp Lazear but to meet two or three of the people they have heard me talk
about so often and I am especially anxious also that they have this pleasure
for reasons which I shall summarize briefly. Please consider the rest of this
letter semi-confidential. I am not sure how much of the following the Gawnes
and Lazears know. They know some of it. It is a touchy subject and even if
they know all of it they may or may not be willing to discuss it. Neverthe-
less, I want you to know it so that you will understand that there is some
delicacy to the matter of their visit and that it represents much more than
a casual visit.

You will remember that in the spring of 1900, Mrs. Jesse Lazear and their
baby boy, Houston, were stationed at Camp Columbia with Doctor Lazear, but
he sent his wife and little boy back to the States for two reasons: She
was pregnant and, secondly, the yellow fever epidemic was impending. Mrs.
Lazear went to Boston and the little girl was born just about the time
Doctor Lazear died. He never saw her. Doctor Lazear had intended to ask
for a leave that spring and go to Boston to be with his wife at the time
of her delivery. Then he got caught up in the yellow fever business and,
to top matters, was appointed to the Army's Yellow Fever Board. Because
of this tremendous challenge to his scientific interests as well as to his
sense of duty, he must have decided not to ask for the furlough or to be
with his wife at the time of her delivery. But the trouble was in order
not to worry his wife, he could not tell her exactly what he was doing or
why he couldn't come home to be with her (I have some of his letters
written to her from Cuba at that time and some of those written by him
to his own mother; they indicate that his wife was getting concerned and
that, seemingly, some little friction was arising because she simply
couldn't understand why he couldn't come to be with her. She apparently
thought that his duty at that time was with her, especially as he had a
leave coming up.).

It is important to understand this background. Doctor Lazear wrote his
wife two or three cryptic notes hinting vaguely that he was involved in
something big connected with yellow fever and yet trying not to frighten
her with the knowledge of the inoculations. Then suddenly, without warning,
Mrs. Lazear received the blunt telegraphic news that Doctor Lazear had died.
She didn't even know he was sick and the telegram announcing his death was
delayed twelve hours in reaching her because the Surgeon General's Office in
Washington didn't know her exact Boston address.

Remember that at this time Major Reed was in Washington, having been recalled
to finish the typhoid fever report. He knew a little more about Lazear's
sickness and death but not very much more than Mrs. Lazear. The latter
hastened to Washington to visit Reed to find out the details of her husband's
death. Unannounced, she merely sent in her name, M.H. Lazear. Reed ex-
pected to meet a male relative and was surprised to meet Mrs. Lazear, also
embarrassed because he could tell her so little. As a result, the “bitterness”
which had begun to develop before her pregnancy/delivery in Boston was
crystallized and she allowed herself to believe that her husband had more or
less abandoned her in favor of some scientific foolishness and had been so
careless as to let himself get killed.

Unfortunate consequences resulted. She more or less cut herself off from
the Lazear relatives (all easterners), went back to California (her home)
and raised her children there with the notion that their father had done
some reprehensible thing, more or less abandoning her and dying, leaving
her with no money and two little children to support. It was years before
Doctor Lazear's two children knew the facts.

The eastern Lazears tried to keep in touch with Mrs. Lazear but fundamentally
she was a sensitive, diffident and somewhat “difficult” person with intense
feelings which she tried to hide but which broke out at times. Only a year
or so before Mrs. Lazear died, and I hope through my correspondence and
visits with her, did she fully understand the situation and (as I understand
it) begin correspondence with the eastern Lazears.

The latter have been of course increasingly proud of their relative and their
interest in him has been growing apace. They are fine people. Captain Gawne
was an outstanding naval officer and I believe was a temporary admiral during
World War II, retiring recently with the permanent rank of captain. Mrs.
Gawne is a very intelligent, charming woman. John Lazear was, around 1910-12
a schoolmate of mine at Pittsburgh. Incidentally, he married a very wealthy
wife whom I have met only casually. They are so anxious to renew their con-
tacts with the Lazear children, Houston and Peggy, both of whom live in
California. They were delighted to hear of the dedication of Camp Lazear
and of the more recent honors (Finlay Medals) to Houston and Peggy. They
are collecting data on the family history, especially concerning Jesse and
they are also anxious, in a delicate way, to have Doctor Lazear's grave
marked appropriately. Because of the misunderstanding noted above, I
don't believe Mrs. Lazear ever saw Doctor Lazear's grave. His body was re-
turned from Cuba to Baltimore and buried there by the eastern relatives.
One of the saddest and strangest moments came to me when I first met Houston
Lazear, the son, and he turned to me and said, “Doctor Hench, where is my
father buried?”

I am so anxious, therefore, for my friends in Cuba to give these closest
living relatives* of Doctor Lazear a suitable welcome. Their visit to
Camp Lazear will mean a tremendous thing spiritually, for them and they
will come home prepared to do for their relative what has not yet been
done - improve the grave and see to it that their connections with the
children of Doctor Lazear and improved, the family ties strengthened and
the ranks closed.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
* (except the two children)
